Negative effects of network latencies in immersive collaborative virtual environments
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 30 August 2019

Negative effects of network latencies in immersive collaborative virtual environments

  • Armin Becher  ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-8160-86371,
  • Jens Angerer2 &
  • Thomas Grauschopf1 

Virtual Reality (2019)Cite this article

  • 125 Accesses

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The present work aims to investigate the negative effects of network latencies in immersive collaborative virtual environments. A user study was conducted to determine the impact of those delays on the performance of users. Participants of the study played a simple cooperative game designed for two players. The goal of the game was to correctly place bicolored cubes into their specific destinations. Since each player only saw the colors of the cubes of his or her partner, both players had to visually and verbally exchange information to complete the game. Each pair of participants played the game under four different latency conditions. The task performance was measured by the time needed to place one cube successfully. Besides, other subjectively observable variables were investigated. The results of the study show that a high end-to-end delay between two VR stations has an adverse effect on the users’ task performance, the amount of mutual understanding and the perceived workload. For the co-presence metric, i.e., the perceived amount of togetherness inside the virtual environment, no significant correlation to the network delay could be determined.

Introduction

Virtual reality (VR) technologies are used in a wide variety of different applications in various industry branches. They can be used for industrial design tasks (Lawson et al. 2016), training simulations (Gavish et al. 2013), medical surgeries (Schreuder et al. 2014), and many other scenarios where working in a virtual environment is beneficial and saves time or cost.

Compared to the real-world, VR allows new ways of worldwide collaboration that would otherwise require expensive, time-consuming, and environmentally harmful long-haul flights. With so-called distributed VR systems, or immersive collaborative virtual environments (ICVEs) (Steptoe et al. 2010), it is possible to work together with other people inside a shared virtual 3D space.

In 1996, Olof Hagsand described a VR system that enables globally distributed users to communicate with each other inside a shared virtual environment. After he pointed out the system’s capabilities, he outlined one of the significant challenges when designing distributed virtual worlds: network latency between different VR locations. He concluded that “in such an environment, it is crucial that participants experience “acceptable” delays.” (Hagsand 1996). He did not further specify an acceptable latency threshold for distributed VR systems.

Motivation

Much research has been done concerning the effects of network latencies in distributed VR applications (Shin Park and Kenyon 1999; Chen et al. 2005; Wu et al. 2010; Su et al. 2013). Though an acceptable latency threshold for complex and multi-modal ICVEs has not yet been determined and requires further research. Nguyen and Duval (2014) wrote that “the problem from network delays is one of the main reasons of ineffective collaborations and inconsistency in interactions of collaborators in CVEs.”

Therefore, the effects of network latencies in ICVEs will be examined in this work. The overarching goal is to determine an acceptable latency threshold for efficient collaboration in distributed VR systems. One of the challenges with such an investigation is the measurement of end-to-end network delays. While previous research in that field determined and controlled the network latency between two dispersed VR systems, the actual end-to-end motion and sound latency have not been taken into account.

Hypotheses

It will be investigated what amount of latency negatively affects the task performance of users inside ICVEs. As it has been shown in previous studies, network delays have a negative impact on the performance of players in simple distributed VR games (Shin Park and Kenyon 1999; Wu et al. 2010; Chen et al. 2005). In this work, the influence on users’ task performance will be investigated using a more complex and highly collaborative task. Users have to exchange information to be successful in the given collaborative game. They can communicate with each other via visual and auditive cues.

In addition to task performance, other effects of network latencies will also be examined. One of these is the perceived feeling of togetherness, which is often referred to as co-presence. Previous studies suggest that there might be a negative correlation between network latencies and co-presence (Su et al. 2014). Like task performance, the influence of network latencies on co-presence will be researched in a multi-modal distributed VR simulation.

Another variable that will be taken into account is mutual understanding. For telephone calls, it is known that high network delays lead to considerable communication difficulties (Kitawaki and Itoh 1991). It is very likely that this effect also occurs in distributed VR systems. It will be examined at which latency threshold mutual understanding between users will be negatively influenced.

The last variable for this study is the effect of network delay on the perceived workload of users. It has been shown that network latency in ICVEs can lead to frustration and confusion (Roberts et al. 2009). For the collaborative game used in this study, users have to solve a given task under time pressure. If the delay between users rises, it is assumed that the task will be more difficult for participants and that the perceived workload increases.

Overall, this leads to the following four hypotheses:

  • The task performance decreases if the network latency increases.

  • There is a correlation between increasing network latencies and a decreased sense of togetherness.

  • Mutual understanding decreases if the network latency rises.

  • There is an increase in perceived workload if network latency rises.

Immersive collaborative virtual environment

The proposed immersive collaborative virtual environment consists of two identical VR stations which are connected via WLAN. The average round-trip time between both clients is 2 ms (average result of 30 ICMP echo requests). Therefore, the one-way network latency is about 1 ms.

Two HTC Vive HMDs with backpack computersFootnote 1 are used for both VR stations. Using a short cable to connect the Vive to the backpack PC allows users to walk freely without the restrictions of cable-bound solutions. The resolution of the HTC Vive is 1080 times 1200 pixel per eye. The Vive deluxe audio strapFootnote 2 was used to make it easier to put on and take off the HMD. Windows 10 was running on both backpack PCs, and no other applications except the ones relevant for the study were running. The interpupillary distance (IPC) was set to a fixed value and not adjusted to the actual anatomy of individual users.

Figure 1 shows a user wearing the backpack PC with the connected HMD.

Two identical VR setups are installed in two different rooms of the same size. The square area in which the HMD and hand controllers are tracked is approximately \(9\,m^2\). The Vive’s room scale area is calibrated so that a user cannot reach the walls when standing at the edge of the tracking boundaries.

Users can interact with the virtual world using two HTC Vive controllers. Virtual 1:1 scale representations of the hardware devices are rendered inside VR. To interact with the virtual world, only the trigger button is needed.

For audio communication between both users, headsets are used. An external voice over IP (VoIP) toolFootnote 3 allows dispersed users to talk to each other via the WLAN network. To improve the immersion of the VR scenario, spatial audio is added to the VR scene. Spatial audio allows both users inside the virtual world to locate each other acoustically.

Latency

Controlled network conditions

The software Clumsy 0.2Footnote 4 is used to control the network latency between both VR stations. Clumsy allows inbound and outbound package filtering and can emulate different network conditions. The tool allows to add a delay to every filtered package. Clumsy is used to control the bi-directional network communication between both computers.

Measurement of end-to-end latency

To determine the end-to-end latencies between both systems, a latency technique developed by Becher et al. (2018) was used.

First, the local motion-to-photon latency of the VR systems was determined. Because both VR PCs are identical, no difference in local latency was assumed. Therefore, all measurements for the local motion-to-photon latency were done on one PC.

After measuring the local delay, the remote latency between both stations was determined. There was a slight difference between both directions. A reason for this might be that on one of the computers, the server processes for the network synchronization were running. Table 1 summarizes the results for the local and remote motion-to-photon latency.

The mouth-to-ear latency was determined with the same measurement setup described by Becher et al. (2018). The end-to-end delay between both stations is shown in Table 2. The local mouth-to-ear latency was not taken into account. The headsets are not acoustically isolated, and both users can hear their own voices while speaking.

As shown in Tables 1 and 2, the motion-to-photon and mouth-to-ear latency between both stations are approximately the same. Therefore, no synchronization mechanism is required.

The grand mean of all remote end-to-end delays (mouth-to-ear and motion-to-photon latency) is about 83 ms. Because the actual delay between both systems is fluctuating (see the minimum and maximum measurements in Tables 1 and 2), an exact specification of the base remote end-to-end latency is not possible. The delay is rounded to the next decimal place. Therefore, the end-to-end delay of the ICVE will further be assumed to be 80 ms.

To show that the network tool Clumsy described in Sect. 3.1 works as expected, the end-to-end latency between both stations was also measured with an artificially added delay of 500 ms. Tables 1 and 2 show that the expected delay approximately matches with the measured end-to-end latencies.

Cube challenge

In the study, pairs of users play four rounds of a collaborative game. The game is especially designed for dyadic collaboration. To complete the game successfully, both users have to exchange information via verbal and visual cues. The developed game will further be called Cube Challenge.

A team of two users shares the same virtual environment. The other player’s head position and the location of the other user’s hand controllers are rendered inside the virtual world. Figure 3 shows how users perceive each other inside the virtual world. The 3D head model has the size of an adult male head.

The avatar representation allows limited non-verbal communication between users. Users can use pointing gestures inside the virtual world to refer to objects. Because of tracked head position, it is also possible to estimate the other person’s line of vision. Users cannot communicate non-verbally using body postures, facial expressions, or eye movements.

In Cube Challenge, both players have to work together to place the bicolored cubes in the corresponding goals/targets. All cubes have a side length of 20 cm and are rendered opaque, whereas all goals are slightly transparent. For every cube exists exactly one matching target which consists of the same two colors as the cube. In total, there are ten cubes which need to be placed in their corresponding goals.

At the beginning of each game, all cubes are arranged in a circle with a radius of 1.4 m around the center of the virtual environment. Each cube is placed on a random position of the circle. All ten targets are randomly placed in another concentric circle with a smaller radius than that of the cubes (0.5 m). The cubes and goals are then rotated into a random starting position. For the rotation, a step size of \(90^\circ \) is used. Figure 2 shows one possible cube and target arrangement.

The objective of a team is to correctly place as many cubes as possible within 2 min. Cubes can be moved by using one of the Vive controllers. If a user holds the trigger button while the controller collides with a cube, the object gets attached to the virtual hand of that user. The cube can then be moved within the virtual world. Releasing the trigger detaches the carried cube. There is no gravity added to the scene, and therefore cubes will not fall but remain at their position in space if a player does not move them. Placing a cube close to a target (approximately 15 cm) will cause the cube to align with the transformation of this goal. This snapping mechanism makes it easier to place the cubes.

As shown in Figs. 2a, b, half of the cubes are bicolored for one player and shown in plain white for the other. Each player can only grab and place white cubes and is not able to move the bicolored objects in the scene. He or she has no information about the colors and rotation of the movable cubes and does not know to which goal a specific white cube belongs. Only the other player has this knowledge and needs to communicate it with his or her partner. Scoring is only possible by sharing information and helping the other player to place his or her cubes correctly.

Figure 3 shows two users playing Cube Challenge. The player in Fig. 3b is holding a white cube and does not know to which goal the cube belongs to. The other player (Fig. 3a) sees that it is a red-purple colored cube which also needs to be rotated to fit into the goal right next to the player (bottom right in Fig. 3b).

The game is over if all ten goals are placed correctly or if 2 min have passed. During the game, a countdown shows how much time is left for placing the cubes. At the beginning of each round, the timer is set to 2 min. When a time-out occurs, the correctly placed cubes are the achieved score of a player. In Fig. 3, the countdown timer can be seen in the background.

All users play Cube Challenge four times and fill in a questionnaire after each round. All questions can be answered from inside the virtual environment, and both users can keep the HMD on for the length of the study. A user who fills in the questionnaire from within the virtual environment is shown in Fig. 4.

Comparison to previous work

The two virtual reality systems in this work consist of an HMD, two VR controllers, and stereo headphones. In CVEs of previous work concerning the effects of end-to-end latencies, nonimmersive displays (Schroeder et al. 2001; Roberts et al. 2003; Shin Park and Kenyon 1999) or cave automatic virtual environments (CAVEs) (Wu et al. 2010; Su et al. 2013) were used.

Using the external tracking system of the HTC Vive allows free locomotion inside the virtual world. In most of the previous studies, it was either only possible to stay at one position in space (Shin Park and Kenyon 1999; Wu et al. 2010), or the virtual environment was larger than the tracking area of the VR system (Schroeder et al. 2001; Roberts et al. 2003). In those cases where the virtual world exceeded the tracking area, artificial locomotion was necessary (e.g., moving through the virtual world using a joystick).

Another difference to the systems used in previous work is that two tracked hand controllers are used. In most of the previous studies, only one hand controller was used to interact with the virtual world (Schroeder et al. 2001; Roberts et al. 2003; Shin Park and Kenyon 1999). Steed et al. (2005) compared different collaborative tasks and investigated how participants behaved inside the virtual environment. Among other tasks, they used the Gazebo (Roberts et al. 2003) and Rubik’s Cube (Schroeder et al. 2001) game. They found that the non-tracked hand was a problem in some situations; for example, if one player accidentally used his or her untracked hand to explain something.

Different to the Gazebo or Rubik’s Cube tasks, Su et al. (2014) investigated the effects of network latency on human-to-human collaborative tasks. In their study, they subjectively evaluated the tolerable latency between two actors while shaking hands. They assumed that the illusion of being on the same stage with other actors breaks if network latencies are above a certain threshold. The drawback with their approach is that it cannot be evaluated objectively.

The basic idea of the collaborative game Cube Challenge is based on the Rubik’s Cube task of Schroeder et al. (2001). Like the Rubik’s Cube puzzle, Cube Challenge is an object-focused and avatar-mediated task. Users have to be aware of what the other player’s avatar is currently trying to do. Different to the Rubik’s Cube game, collaboration is an essential part in Cube Challenge. As Roberts et al. (2003) outlined when comparing the Rubik’s Cube game with the Gazebo task, the collaboration between users might improve the performance, but it is not necessary for winning the game. This means that a team can be successful in the Rubik’s Cube challenge without collaborating with the partner. It is possible to solve the puzzle alone. In Cube Challenge, collaboration is mandatory. Without sharing information with the other user inside the virtual environment, it is not possible to win the game.

In comparison with the Gazebo task, the collaborative activities in Cube Challenge are less complex. No subtasks, no virtual tools, and also no activities which must be performed by two players at the same time are required. Keeping the task simple makes it possible to explain the game quickly and play several rounds. Inexperienced users required more than 12 min to finish the Gazebo task (Roberts et al. 2003). With the time limit of 2 min, one round of Cube Challenge is about six times shorter. This makes the task suitable to test the performance of many users under several network latency conditions.

Experimental design

Independent variable—latency

Network delay between both VR stations is the only controlled variable of the described experiment. As shown in Sect. 3, the base end-to-end latency between both stations is approximately 80 ms.

Each participant in the study plays the game Cube Challenge four times. In each round, the network latency changes. One of the four rounds is played with no additional latency. For the other rounds, delays of 150, 300, and 450 ms are added to the base network delay of 80 ms. Therefore, the actual remote motion-to-photon and mouth-to-ear delays are 80, 230, 380, and 530 ms. The latency levels are selected based on the findings of previous researchers.

The highest artificially added delay of 450 ms (530 ms of total end-to-end latency) is used because previous studies showed that this amount of lag might occur in real scenarios. For example, Roberts et al. investigated the motion-to-photon delay between an ICVE and a video conference system (Roberts et al. 2009). They measured a mean end-to-end delay from a contemporary display to an immersive environment of 605 ms. Conversely, they determined a delay of 414 ms.

Another reason to choose a maximum end-to-end delay above 500 ms is based on a recommendation of the ITU Telecommunication Standardization Sector (ITU). The ITU-T develops technical standards for telecommunication. They specified that a mouth-to-ear latency of about 500 ms is unsatisfactory for the majority of users (International Telecommunication Union 2003).

Considering all the suggestions and research results described above, the highest end-to-end delay for the study is set to 530 ms (450 ms of additional delay).

The lowest artificially added latency of 150 ms is used because some findings of previous researchers suggest that delays below 150 ms are not noticeable (Su et al. 2014; Chen et al. 2005).

For the fourth and final latency scenario, an artificial delay of 300 ms is used. In the study by Chen et al. (2005), a delay between 150 and 300 ms had a slight impact on the task performance.

Playing Cube Challenge for several rounds might lead to better performance due to a training effect. To ensure that the sequence of latency conditions does not affect the study, permutations of all delay steps are used. Since there are four different latency conditions, 24 permutations are possible.

Dependent variables

Task performance

The users’ performance while playing Cube Challenge is one of the examined dependent variables in this study. As discussed in Sect. 1.1, the study aims to determine a threshold for the delay at which the team’s performance decreases.

To measure the task performance, the achieved goals and the time needed for one round of the game are recorded. Each round is limited to 120 s. If this time limit is exceeded, no more cubes can be placed, and all correctly positioned objects represent the score of the current round. To compare the results later on, the average required time to place one cube in a given round is calculated.

Co-presence

One of the hypotheses of this work is that the perceived amount of togetherness is negatively influenced by network latencies. The feeling of being together with somebody inside a virtual environment is often referred to as co-presence (Alahuhta et al. 2016; Slater et al. 2000; Biocca et al. 2003). Su et al. (2014) investigated the effects of network latencies on collaborative acting. Although they did not mention the term co-presence, they assumed that latency would negatively affect the illusion of being at the same place.

For this work, a questionnaire is used to evaluate co-presence. The assumption is that the sense of being together inside the same virtual environment will decrease with an increase in network latency.

One of the first co-presence questionnaires was developed by Steed et al. (1999). One year later, Basdogan et al. (2000) used the same eight questions like in Steed et al. (1999), but in greater detail. Like in Nam et al. (2008), the questionnaire of this study consists of a subset of four questions based on the above-mentioned questionnaire. As in the original version, a seven-point Likert scale is used (Steed et al. 1999).

First, users are asked whether they had the feeling of being together in the same room with their partner. Afterward, they were asked if they had the feeling of directly working together with another person. The next question was about whether the experience was like a real experience where users collaborated with another person. Finally, participants were asked if the experience of being together was similar to a real-world scenario.

The questions used by Steed et al. (1999) and Basdogan et al. (2000) concerning whether a person perceived the co-worker to be real were not used in this study. The reason for this is that audio communication between the two users is possible, and it is unlikely that a person will be perceived as not real.

Mutual understanding

Another variable investigated in this study is mutual understanding. It was first used by Biocca et al. (2001) to investigate the difference between face-to-face and computer-mediated interactions.

Awareness of others and communication between users are essential to collaborate successfully inside ICVEs (Nguyen and Duval 2014). Communication is a mandatory part of Cube Challenge. Only if users share information and understand each other they can complete the game.

By measuring the variable mutual understanding via a questionnaire, it is possible to detect if and at what level of network latency users start to misunderstand their partner. All six items of the survey of Biocca et al. (2001) with a seven-point Likert scale were used for this study.

Perceived workload

The last hypothesis of this work is that the perceived workload of users will rise with an increase in network latency. As Roberts et al. (2003) outlined, large network delays might lead to confusion and frustration in virtual environments.

For the task, Cube Challenge, it can be assumed that users will be more stressed if the network latency is high. Due to the limit of 2 min, users are under time pressure. With high network delays, users will need more time to place the individual cubes correctly, while the timer indicates that they are running out of time. This will presumably increase the stress level of the participants.

Measuring the perceived workload also helps to classify the collaborative task. By distinguishing between different types of workload (e.g., mental demand, physical demand, temporal demand, performance, effort, and frustration), it is possible to see how challenging Cube Challenge is.

To measure the perceived workload, the NASA Task Load Index (NASA TLX) is used (Hart and Staveland 1988). The subjective workload of users is divided into the following six subcategories: mental demand, physical demand, temporal demand, performance, effort, and frustration level.

For the variables physical and mental demand, it is expected that there is no difference between the rounds played. The task remains the same in each round, and users will walk more or less the same distances. The questions of the NASA TLX refer explicitly to the given task and not the personally perceived mental or physical strain.

For the remaining four subcategories of the NASA TLX (temporal demand, performance, effort, and frustration), it is assumed that latencies will have a negative impact. Therefore, the overall measured workload is expected to rise with an increase in network delay.

In contrast to the seven-point Likert scale used for the variables mutual understanding and co-presence, the perceived workload is measured with a fine-grained scale of 20 levels. The final rating is multiplied by 5 to get a range between 0 and 100 points (Hart and Staveland 1988).

Procedure

The whole study takes about 45 min for each pair of subjects. Both users are informed about the study and what they will see and do in virtual reality. They are not told about the aim of the study. Therefore, users do not know beforehand that different levels of latency will be added while playing the game. A paper version of the questionnaire is used to explain the aim of the different questions and to outline the different rating scales. Especially, the NASA TLX is described in more detail because the descriptions for every sub-task are important, and the scaling and scale annotation differ from all other questions. After that, the game Cube Challenge gets explained. Both participants practice the game in a training phase. After the training, four time-limited game rounds start.

While explaining what they will do in VR and how the study is structured, users are encouraged to ask questions. Only after both users confirmed that they understood the procedure, they are asked to fill in a consent form. They are also informed that each of them can interrupt the study at any time. Then, the users are led to different rooms and supported to put on the VR system. After the participants are fully equipped with hand controllers and headsets, they have to confirm that they can see and hear each other inside the virtual world.

The supervisor can see what both users perceive through their HMDs and is also able to communicate with the participants during the study via a headset. The whole VR session takes between 20 and 30 min.

Training phase

For the training phase, users have to place all ten cubes in their corresponding goals. The training phase ends if all ten cubes are placed correctly. No time-out was used during the training phase. Both players can figure out their way of solving Cube Challenge. If they have problems understanding the task or interacting with the controller, the supervisor will help them. No additional network latency is added for the training phase. Before placing the last cube, the supervisor informs both users that the time-limited game will start afterward. This gives them the possibility to discuss their strategy before actually starting the game.

Main task

A countdown is displayed in the field of vision of both users for 5 s. Then, a new round of Cube Challenge starts. Different latency conditions are used for each game round. In total, 24 pairs participated in the study, which is equal to the number of permutations for all latency conditions. Therefore, every combination of added delay is used only once.

During the game, the supervisor only communicates with the users in exceptional circumstances, and for example, if technical problems occur and the study needs to be interrupted. Another reason to communicate with the players is if they place all the cubes in goals, but not all cubes are rotated correctly. In this situation, the supervisor informs them that one or more cubes are not correctly aligned.

After both players won the game or if 2 min are over, all parts of Cube Challenge disappear and both users have to fill in the virtual questionnaire. As soon as both players have finished their questionnaire, the supervisor starts the next game round. After playing four rounds of Cube Challenge and answering all four questionnaires, the supervisor helps both users with taking off the VR systems.

Open feedback

When the VR session is over, both participants are asked several questions in an open feedback talk.

The first question is whether they had any problems using the VR system. Afterward, they are asked whether they had any problems with rotating 3D objects mentally. Two additional questions are asked to see how much VR and gaming experience they have. Participants are prompted whether they have already played 3D computer games or if they have used an HMD before.

Before the disclosure that different amounts of latency were added to all rounds of Cube Challenge, users were asked whether they detected any changes between the rounds and if so, how they noticed it. After that, all the remaining questions were asked. Now that they were informed that artificial delays were added, users have been asked whether they detected the delays. If they did, they were asked in which rounds they recognized the delays. After that, they were encouraged to list other things which they found to be disruptive. Subsequently, they said whether they could imagine using an ICVE system like this in practice. Finally, all subjects were asked to give free feedback.

Subjects

All subjects are employees of the AUDI AG or a partner company. The sample size of the study is 48 people. Therefore, 24 different teams played the game Cube Challenge.

Each person was randomly paired with another participant. Only eight people knew each other before participating in the study. Therefore, the majority of all users saw their partner for the first time when they participated in the study.

Some questions from the open feedback talk are used to characterize the participants of the study further. All users confirmed that they had no significant problems using the VR system. No user declared that he or she was not able to rotate 3D objects mentally.

Nearly two-thirds of the users have played 3D computer games in the past, and about 80% of all participants used VR headset before. Table 3 summarizes the VR experience of all users. Most of the subjects who had experience with VR declared that they have never been immersed in a virtual environment for longer than 30 min. Due to data protection guidelines, age, gender, and educational background were not recorded.

Results

Although all users were informed that they could abort the study whenever they wanted, none of them did. All 48 subjects successfully finished the four rounds of Cube Challenge.

Performance

Figure 5 summarizes the performance results for different latency conditions. There is one outlier for a delay of 450 ms. One pair of users achieved only two goals. Therefore, the performance score for those two users is 60 s. The outlier was not caused by technical problems. Both users had difficulties in understanding their partner’s intentions due to the high network delay.

An analysis of variance showed that there is a significant difference between at least one of the four latency conditions \((\textit{F}_{3,188} = 15.77, \,\textit{p} < .001)\).

In Table 4, the results of the post hoc test and the computed effect sizes are summarized. Only an added delay of 450 ms is significantly different in comparison with all other conditions.

The dependent variable task performance differed significantly under various latency conditions. Interestingly, only an artificially added delay of 450 ms was significant compared to all other latency scenarios. The difference is still significant when the pair of participants who only managed to place two cubes correctly (see the outlier in Fig. 5) were removed from the results.

The results show that the performance slightly decreased for different latency levels and declined sharply at 450 ms. The steep decrease in performance for the 450 ms game rounds leads to a large effect size (Cohen’s d > 1).

In general, it can be concluded that latency has an impact on task performance, and the first hypothesis (see Sect. 1.2) can be confirmed. For the given collaborative game, the task performance decreased with an increase in network latency.

Co-presence

Overall users evaluated the perceived co-presence in the experiment as high. The grand mean for the dependent variable co-presence is about \(5.97\pm 0.93\) out of seven points.

The measured co-presence score for the different latency conditions is summarized in Fig. 6. No significant effect of latency on perceived co-presence was detected with the analysis of variance (F\(_{3,188}\) = 1.892, p > .1).

The results show that the perceived amount of co-presence is not significantly influenced by an increase in network latency. Even at a total delay of 530 ms, the co-presence rating was high. The hypothesis for the dependent variable co-presence can be falsified. Therefore, the chosen amount of artificially added latency does not negatively influence the perceived co-presence of users.

Two participants mentioned that they perceived a higher sense of co-presence after playing the game for several rounds. Although there is a slight trend toward an increased feeling of co-presence for the last two rounds (a score of 6.25 compared to 6), an ANOVA shows that this difference is also not significant \((\textit{F}_{3,188} = 1.886,\,\textit{p}> .1)\).

In general, users evaluated the sense of being with their partner in the same virtual environment as high. This might also explain why so many users mentioned that walking through others inside the virtual environment felt strange. Keeping a certain amount of interpersonal distance between users is a social norm that also applies to virtual worlds (Yee et al. 2007).

Mutual understanding

Like co-presence, mutual understanding was also rated high. The grand mean for the co-presence rating is \(5.83\pm 1.03\). Figure 7 shows the different scores for the category mutual understanding at various latency conditions.

An ANOVA test showed that there is a significant difference between at least one of the latency conditions \((\textit{F}_{3,188} = 7.989, \,\textit{p} < .001)\). Table 5 summarizes the results of a post hoc (Tukey) test and shows the effect sizes. Again, only the 450 ms condition was significantly different compared to all other delay scenarios.

The hypothesis was that network delays would negatively influence the mutual understanding of users inside the virtual world. Since 450 ms of additional delay lead to a significant decrease in the perceived mutual understanding, the hypothesis can be considered to be true. Therefore, it can be concluded that an increase in network latency results in a decreased understanding between users in ICVEs.

Perceived workload

The perceived workload is measured using the NASA Task Load Index, which is composed of six subcategories. The grand mean workload rating is at around \(35.33\pm 17.21\) points out of 100.

Figure 8 shows the perceived workload ratings at different latency conditions. The results are statistically significant \((\textit{F}_{3,188} = 3.876, \,\textit{p} < .05)\).

Post hoc testing revealed that the difference is only significant for the latency combinations 450 ms & 0 ms and 450 ms & 150 ms (see Table 6).

The hypothesis that the perceived workload is negatively influenced by the end-to-end network latency could be confirmed with the results of the study. At an artificially added delay of 450 ms, the workload increased significantly.

The NASA TLX questionnaire can further be split into six subcategories. The categories are mental demand, physical demand, temporal demand, performance, effort, and frustration. The overall ratings for the different categories for all four latency conditions are visualized in Fig. 9.

Looking at the results in Fig. 9 shows that Cube Challenge is mainly a task which has a high temporal demand and high effort. The mental workload is also a bit higher than the remaining three categories: physical demand, performance, and frustration. Those last three categories are rated lower compared to the other NASA TLX questions (median score of about 20).

In the following subsections, the six categories of the NASA TLX will be investigated in greater detail.

Mental demand

The first subcategory of the task load is mental demand. The grand mean rating for that subcategory is \(35.70\pm 23.12\). As expected, ANOVA showed no significant difference between the four latency conditions \((\textit{F}_{3,188} = 1.363,\,\textit{p} > .1)\). The reason for this is that the task inside the virtual environment did not change between the different latency conditions. It was not expected that users would have to think more if the network latency increases.

Physical demand

Like mental demand, it was not expected that latency would have an impact on the NASA TLX subcategory physical demand. The analysis of variance showed no significant differences between all four latency conditions (F\(_{3,188}\) = 0.151, ns). Users had to walk similar distances in every round. Overall, users evaluated Cube Challenge as a not physically demanding task (mean \(25.34\pm 19.03\)).

Temporal demand

The temporal demand is perceived with \(49.84\pm 24.71\) points as the highest of all TLX categories. An ANOVA test revealed that the results for the temporal demand were also not significant \(({F}_{3,188} = 2.527, \,{p} > .05)\).

For the temporal demand, it was expected that network latencies would have a negative impact. The assumption was that users would perceive more temporal stress if they do not manage to place all the cubes within the time limit of 2 min.

The results of this study showed that this is not the case. No significant correlation between network latency and the temporal demand was detected. The mean difference between the base latency and 450 ms is about 28%, and the F-Value of the ANOVA test is slightly below the threshold of 2.65.

The limited number of study participants (\(n=48\)) might be the reason that the effect of network latency on the temporal demand could not be discovered in this work.

Another explanation is that users did not even realize that they were running out of time and therefore perceived no temporal stress. As the results of the open feedback questionnaire show (see Sect. 7.5.4), some users mentioned that they did not notice the countdown timer inside the virtual world.

Performance

The mean performance rating was \(28.88\pm 25.08\). Figure 10 summarizes the ratings for different latency conditions. An ANOVA test revealed a significant difference between the latency conditions \(({F}_{3,188} = 7.364,\, {p} < .001)\).

The Tukey test showed that there is a significant difference between the 450 ms and all other latency conditions (see Table 7).

The perceived performance is very similar to the measured task performance. An artificially added delay of 450 ms yields significantly different results compared to all other scenarios. Although a small increase for the 300 ms condition can be seen (see Fig. 10), but that difference is not significant.

In summary, it can be concluded that the perceived performance matches with the results for the objectively measured task performance of users.

Effort

Effort is the fifth subcategory of the NASA Task Load Index. It was rated high compared to the other results (mean \(45.26\pm 23.91\)). No significant correlation between latency and effort could be determined \((\textit{F}_{3,188} = 1.474, \,\textit{p} > .1)\).

Like for the temporal demand subcategory, this result was not expected. The assumption was that users would work harder to accomplish their goal because they realize that they are running out of time.

Maybe the reason for this is the same as already mentioned in the temporal demand section. Users may not have noticed that they were running out of time and did not even realize that they have to work harder to accomplish their objectives.

Frustration

Like physical demand and performance, the grand mean frustration level was low (mean \(26.95\pm 21.24\)). ANOVA revealed that the frustration levels for the latency categories shown in Fig. 11 are significantly different \((\textit{F}_{3,188} = 2.798, \,\textit{p} < .05)\).

Post hoc testing showed that the difference is only significant for one latency combination. Only the 450 ms condition showed a significant difference compared to the 150 ms scenario (see Table 8).

It was assumed that higher latencies would be more annoying for users and the level of frustration would rise accordingly. It was unexpected that only the 450 ms condition is significant to the 150 ms condition, but not to the base delay.

Again, the assumption is that the small sample size causes this effect. The p value for the 0 ms and 450 ms condition is relatively small with approximately 17%. For a greater sample size, it is likely that a significant difference could be detected.

Open feedback

Some answers from the open feedback questions are already used to characterize the subjects (see Sect. 6.5).

Latency perception

Before explaining that different amounts of latencies were added to the game rounds, participants were asked whether they noticed any difference between the four rounds of Cube Challenge and if so, how they became aware of it.

Of the 48 users, 29 failed to mention the increased network delay when asked whether they detected any changes. Some participants noticed a difference but could not give an explanation.

Some of those users reported that the number of cubes changed or that the cubes were in a favorable start position for some rounds. Others mentioned that they thought the time limit was shorter than 2 min and it was harder for them to place all cubes correctly. Some participants said that they performed better in later rounds because they got used to the game and were better coordinated.

After explaining the aim of the study and revealing that various levels of latency were added to the game rounds, 39 out of 48 users reported that they noticed the delay in one or more rounds.

For those users who reported that they felt the latency, the majority of 25 users named the round with an artificially added delay of 450 ms. Eleven participants said that they detected the delay in the game with an artificial delay of 300 ms. Only three participants named the round with 150 ms additional latency to be delayed. None of the users named the round with the base latency.

Shortcomings

Users gave very different answers when they were asked for things that they found distracting while playing the game. Sixteen people said that the avatar representation was not good enough. Four people said that virtual hands instead of controllers would have been a useful feature. Six users stated that the head representation was insufficient. They were unable to see where precisely the partner was looking at and missed the ability to use facial expressions. Another six users said that they would have liked a full-body avatar representation inside the virtual environment.

A bit more than half of the subjects (26 people) who reported a shortcoming mentioned technical limitations of the VR system to be distracting. Ten said that the resolution of the display system was not high enough; especially when reading the text of the VR questionnaire. For other users, the HMD was too heavy, uncomfortable or too hot (eight users). Three users reported that the audio quality was not good enough. Two said that the echo (caused by the network latency) was distracting. One mentioned the spatial-audio implementation to be disruptive.

Practical application

All participants were asked whether they could imagine using the distributed VR system professionally. All users answered yes to this question. Without asking them, ten of the participants named different tasks where they thought that collaborative VR environments could be helpful in the automotive industry. They listed application areas like construction feasibility studies, research, and development, home office, maintenance, virtual meetings as well as for instructions and training scenarios.

Various

Finally, users could report everything else they noticed while playing Cube Challenge. Thirty participants answered this question.

Since the question was kept very open, the answers were diverse. Nevertheless, half of the subjects who answered mentioned that it felt strange when they walked through virtual objects like cubes or the avatar representation of their partner. Some users said that they avoided walking through other avatars even though they knew that it was possible.

Seven of the subjects who answered this question said that they noticed the countdown timer only in one of the first few rounds or not at all. Since participants were not directly asked whether they saw the timer, the number of users who did not notice it during the game might therefore be a lot higher.

Another thing to note is that none of the users interrupted the study and mentioned that they felt sick afterward. One of the reasons that users did not feel sick or quit the study might be the relatively low local motion-to-photon latency of the VR system. As it has been shown in previous studies, a high local motion-to-photon delay can cause motion sickness (Buker et al. 2012; Pierre et al. 2015).

Summary

After performing an analysis of variance for every dependent variable listed in Sect. 6.2, it can be concluded that three out of four variables are significantly influenced by different levels of network delay. Only for the variable co-presence, it could not be shown that it was affected by different delay conditions.

When the ANOVA of a variable was significant, post hoc analyses revealed that only the 450 ms condition was significantly different compared to at least one of the other conditions. For task performance and mutual understanding, it could be shown that the 450 ms network scenario differs significantly from all other latency conditions. The perceived workload was only statistically different for the 450 ms compared to the 150 ms condition and the base latency scenario. The difference to 300 ms was a lot smaller. Table 9 summarizes all significant results of this study.

Discussion

Comparison to previous work

Comparing the results of this study with previous work shows some similarities but also differences. One of the things that should be noted is that it is not possible to directly compare the results of this study with previous research. The reason for this is that for all previous studies concerning latencies in ICVEs, only the network latency and no end-to-end delay were reported (Shin Park and Kenyon 1999; Chen et al. 2005; Wu et al. 2010). Therefore, it is not possible to directly compare the motion-to-photon or mouth-to-ear latency of this study with previous research and only the artificially added delay is taken into account.

In the Hot Wire game by Shin Park and Kenyon (1999), 200 ms of constant delay yielded, no difference compared to 10 ms. This is in line with the results of this study. The same applies to the findings of Chen et al. (2005). Up to 150 ms no difference in task performance was detected. Chen et al. (2005) measured a rapid performance drop when the network latency exceeded 300 ms. This cannot be confirmed by the results of this study. Although a slight performance decrease at 300 ms was found in this study, ANOVA revealed that this difference is not statistically significant.

The findings of Wu et al. (2010) could not be confirmed in this study. They concluded that a delay of 80–120 ms was disruptive and noticeable for most users. In Cube Challenge, most people noticed the delay between 300 ms and 450 ms. Only three of those users who detected a difference assumed the 150 ms condition to be delayed. It can be concluded that for the given collaborative game of this study the network latency is perceived only at a higher value than for the task of Rope Jumping. An explanation for this could be that timing is an essential part for the Rope Jumping task used by Wu et al.. Only if the user can accurately estimate the position of the rope he or she can jump over the rope without making a mistake by touching it. In contrast, Cube Challenge does not require an exact timing for placing the cubes.

For the collaborative task described by Su et al. (2014), a rapid movement between 150 ms and 200 ms was considered to be tolerable. A delay above 600 ms is mentioned as a threshold for slow movements. The findings of this study suggest that the acceptable delay is somewhere between 300 ms and 450 ms, since many users mentioned those two conditions when they were asked if they detected the delay.

Limitations

As mentioned in the previous section, one of the limitations of this study is the small sample size of 48 subjects/24 pairs. For some variables like the task performance, it is assumed that 300 ms would show a small effect that could not be proven to be significant with the used sample size.

Another problem of the study is the limited avatar representation of users inside the virtual environment. With only a simple 3D-head and two models of the controllers, it might be difficult for users to convey pieces of information non-verbally. About 34% of all participants mentioned the avatar representation to be not good enough.

Having hands in the virtual world might have also helped users to express themselves better if they tried to point to something, or if they explained to their partner how to spin a particular cube. Tracking eye movements could also have been helpful in communication. With only the head rotation and a simple 3D-model, it is hard to tell where the user is looking at inside the virtual world. Using another texture which would make it easier to differentiate between the front and back of a user’s head would have helped here. Those might have lead to misunderstandings and communication problems that are unrelated to the network latency between both VR systems.

Users agreed to participate in the study for about 45 min. Within this time limit, it was possible to play four rounds of Cube Challenge. Having only four different latency conditions for each team is another limitation of this study. With more rounds, finer graduation would have been possible.

As mentioned before, the acceptable network latency threshold is related to the type of collaborative activity. Therefore, it is not possible to determine a general latency threshold for every kind of ICVE systems. The problem of the generalizability of this study will be discussed in the following section.

Generalizability

One of the fundamental challenges in experimental studies is that they are harder to generalize than field studies. A wide variety of ICVE systems exists, which makes it impossible to make general assumptions about latency thresholds for all systems. The findings of this work therefore only apply to a subset of collaborative tasks and types of ICVEs.

Nevertheless, the game Cube Challenge and the distributed VR system have been carefully chosen to be comparable with state-of-the-art ICVE systems. The assumption is that for other avatar-mediated object-focused tasks, the results of this work also apply. Most of the use cases for VR mentioned in the introduction section (see chapter 1) require users to be inside a virtual world together, talk naturally to each other and explain things via pointing gestures. On the hardware side, HTC Vives were used since they are one of the most common commercially available VR systems.

Conclusions

The results of this work provide further details about the acceptable latency threshold in ICVE systems. The findings show that keeping the end-to-end delay between two VR systems below 230 ms will not affect the performance of users and is most likely not even noticed. A delay of about 380 ms is still acceptable for some users, but as the answers to the open feedback questionnaire suggest, about 17% of the subjects already noticed this amount of latency. A total delay of 530 ms leads to a sharp drop in performance, decreases the mutual understanding of users and increases the mental workload. Therefore, this amount of latency is not recommended for collaborative tasks.

All hypotheses of this work (see Sect. 1.2), except for one, could be confirmed. It has been proven that high network delays lead to a performance drop, decrease the mutual understanding and increase the perceived workload of users. Network delays do not influence the amount of co-presence.

Implications for future research

The findings of this work help to evaluate the latency requirements in object-focused avatar-mediated tasks. It would also be interesting to further investigate the effects of network delays on human-to-human collaborative tasks. For interpersonal interactions, the possibility of non-verbal communication inside the virtual environment would be an important component of the ICVE system. Right now, facial expression capturing and full-body tracking are not a feature of commercially available VR system. As soon as these technologies become more sophisticated, it would be interesting to see how latency affects users inside those ICVE systems. Investigating the co-presence and mutual understanding in complex human-to-human collaborative tasks like acting or dancing is also an interesting task for future research.

Varying latencies, network jitter, as well as more extended collaboration with users adapting to the end-to-end delays are also interesting research questions for the future. With cube challenge, users had to cope with fixed latencies over a short time. It would be interesting to investigate further how good people can adapt to fixed delays if they collaborate over a longer period.

Another suggestion for future studies is that the actual end-to-end delay of an ICVE system should be measured and specified. This will help to compare the findings of different studies. In this work, the pure network latency between two systems was only about 2 ms, while the motion-to-photon and mouth-to-ear latency were approximately 80 ms. This significant difference indicates that the system’s end-to-end delay can be a lot higher than the measured network latency. Measuring the end-to-end system latency with a method described by Roberts et al. (2003) or Becher et al. (2018) would help to directly compare the results of different studies in the future.
